Be made of silver or copper: and the end with a pomegranate is inserted into the sickle's mouth until steam rises to the wound above the tube, until it much covers the wound.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then repeat many times over that same one until healed.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 And cut out the swelling before starting treatment for abscesses.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 It is also pleasing to add in an abscess: it is not necessary to do so unless during the descent of the boil, when it is hot.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 But if this instrument is not present with you, then take a cane and prepare its core at the end: so that the patient's skin may not burn; for the core prevents the steam from burning the skin: and this is part of good treatment for health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 § On removing spines, and bones in the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	 Often it clings to the throat: a fishbone or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	 Therefore you should extract what appears above that which has fallen: after pressing the tongue with an instrument towards the light, and it is explained to you what is in the throard.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	 And that which does not appear to you and hides in the throat, it is necessary for a sick person to vomit before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	 For perhaps something attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	 Or a sick person may swallow the end of a pine cone, or the root of lettuce, or a grain of dry bread; or receive the end of sea sponge soaked in milk: and wrap it with woollen thread, then let him swallow the substance.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	 When therefore it reaches the place where there are bones or a bone, and is extracted, then it goes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	 If however it does not go out with that which we have said: then use an instrument of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	 It should be thicker than a little radius, and at the end there should be flexibility that may easily enter its throat: and it itself has an upwardly polished head.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	 And let it be noted by touch of its epiglottis, that no cough may happen to him: and push the bone or spine or insert it with the doctor's hand itself.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	 But indeed the sick person inserts it [the catheter], and this is better: because of his own knowledge about the place annexed to the body; and he pushes downward or pulls up with his hand along with the instrument until fully prepared, then exits.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	 Concerning the removal of leeches [bloodsuckers].
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	 When a leech is being treated with what I mentioned in the division of cure along with medicines, and it does not grow [bloodsuck], then consider whether to have its throat examined by daylight in front of the sun, or under the sun after having pressed its tongue with an instrument that you are familiar with.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	 But if your intuition falls on the leech, remove it with a small hook or with delicate fingers properly positioned.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	 But if it is not possible with them: then take a hollow tube and insert it into the patient's throat up to near the back of the throat; then insert iron heated by fire into the hollowness of the tune.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	 Do this many times: and let the patient abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	 Then receive a full utensil of cold water and open his mouth into it: and wash his own mouth with it, and do not swallow anything from it: and move the water one hour after another by hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	 For the leech then falls immediately when it feels water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	 But if it does not exit with what I have said, then fumigate the patient with fleas or with vinegar using an instrument that you are familiar with in the smoking of a woolen garment.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	 Do this many times, for it is indeed that it falls.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	 And the method of operation in fumigation is that you take a pot where there are green plums with fire; and let the pot be covered with a lid, having an opening in the middle: and insert the end of the instrument into that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	 Then make the person take a suffocation bath and place his sick bone at the tip of the tube, and close his bone so that the suffocation does not escape, until you know that the suffocation has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	 Immediamo che il sanguisughe cadesse immediatamente.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	 Se questo non cade, allora ripeti la suffumigazione molte volte.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	 E sopporti il malato sete e mangi pasti salati, aglio e non beva acqua.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	 Pertanto, è necessario che si esca da questo trattamento.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	 Ecco la tecnica con lo strumento per estrarre il sangue della lebbra quando cade sopra l'orecchio stesso. (Si noti che questo si riferisce probabilamo a un metodo descritto nel contesto, non necessariamente alla sanguisuga come animale
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	 È simile a un paio di pinzette che vedi: se non è stato inserito in modo tale da entrare nella laringe. (Si nota il riferimento alle forcine utilizzate per attaccare la lebbra al bordo della gola, come descritto nel testo originale.)
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	 E la sua estremità è come l'ali di una cicogna che ha un bordo ruvido dove si lega e non lascia mai nulla all'interno. (Si noti il riferimento alle pinzette con le punte ritorte, descritte nel contesto.)
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	 § Su come tagliare un ascesso, la sua sezione e trattamento generale. (Si noti che l'apostema qui si riferisce probabilmente ad una raccolta di pus o
Caput XL.	 Testa 40. (Si tratta di numer
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	 Esistono molte specie di ascessi, di molti tipi, come la nostra memoria ricorda loro; E sono diversi nei metodi della loro perforazione e nella sezione dei medesimi in due modi: (Il testo qui si riferisce alle varietà di ascessi descritte nel contesto.)
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	 Di questi un tipo è una forma specifica di ascesso che deriva dalle umidità: (Si nota il riferimento al tipico crescita dell'ascesso dovuta alla presenza di fluidi corporei in eccesso.)
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	 And the second method depends on the places where it occurs from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	 Since a sore occurrcuing on the head is different from a sore occuring in the anus; and a sore occurrecing at a fleshy place, is different from a sore occurring at joints: each has their own judgement according to its operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	 And from sores are those which should not be perforated unless after the sweating of pus in them and their completion; and among these are those which should be perforated, while they are raw, and do not mature according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	 Like sores that are near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	 For a sore that occurs near a joint and is prolonged to be like its own; until it rots, which may corrupt the ligaments or nerves of that joint connection: thus it is a closer cause for the contraction of that limb part.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	 Or it is a sore on the main limb part; for if you delay its perforation until it matures, it will harm either that, or through that main limb part.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	 Or it is near the anus; therefore its perforation should be immature: and it should not be perforated, a raw sore, not fully digested, unless it is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deep and prolongs to the intestines within, and becomes a fistula, or occurs on its border which cannot heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	 It is necessary for you to know the time of perforation of sores that are matured according to their completion: and it occurs at the easing of pain, reduction of fever, diminishing redness, weakening pulse, and lessening severity of headaches from sores; and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	 And it is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower part of sores, and more prominent; and let the perforation be descending along the body, if the sores are on parts of hands and feet, limbs' ligaments, nerves, arteries, and ultimately in all equal places where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	 In those cases that require reflection, proceed with puncturing according to the aforementanguished limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	 When an abscess is located in fleshy areas: then it is better to delay the puncturing of that one until its digestion has been confirmed, as we mentioned with regard to suppuration.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	 For if you puncture the thing before that: the course of the virus is extended from it, and there are many impurities and discharges, and perhaps its lips harden, and its depths.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	 And some abscesses are punctured according to the width of the body out of necessity: or according to that which requires it of limb.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	 And it is necessary that you administer a slight puncturing in small abscesses, and an ample puncturing in large abscesses: or many sections according to the similarity of the size of the abscesses.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	 And there are from abscesses, in which it is necessary that the skin be chiseled away: and when it has been cut like cloth, and done up on its edge, which already has died: as that happens in many, where it becomes soft, and swellings.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	 And there are from them that have sections with three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	 And there is one of which it becomes like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	 Like an abscess in the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	 And there are from them that a round puncturing is administered, and a crescent-shaped one: and similar to those of the sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	 However, that which does not have a head, such as shallow abscesseras, it is necessary to puncture with a surface puncturing, or merely flat ones.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	 And it is necessary that when an abscess is large and has already collected many healings, and you have punctured its contents, so that you do not withdraw all the pus at once during that time: indeed extract from that very part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	 Then [let] a soft lump from an abscess persist for another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	 Then let something be drawn out of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	 Do that many times gradually, until it is expelled out: especially if the patient is weak due to lack of strength, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man with gray hair: for often the spirit of the living animal is resolved by the passing away from the sickness. And perhaps the weak person dies and you do not notice it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	 Therefore take this chapter with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	 And after your incision, which you make in such abscesses, it should be cleaned to prevent wound; and consider this.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	 If therefore there is a small wound from an abscess, or it is a flat incision, then apply Licinius' liniment, or the ancient lotion of Cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	 And if it is a large abscess, and there are many fissures from the incision, then let you insert Licinium into every fissure until they reach closure.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	 And if in the abscess you have detached part of the skin or pushed it around its edge: then let you fill it with the old Cotton, or as when a cloth is woven, or when lint is carded without moisture: and bind that firmly until on the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then lay it out, and treat it with what you need from an ointnent, until healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	 But if however a flow of blood happens during your time of operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after it has been soaked into the cloths: and place it many times over the place of the blood flow.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	 But if the blood flow persists, then it is necessary to administer a regime and treatment, and powders as described in many places of this book, and division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	 However, if it is during the winter season and the location of the swelling involves many nerves: then one should pour warm vinegar and hot oil into droplets and place them on top of that spot.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	 And if it is during the summer and the areas are fleshy: then one should place droplets soaked in water, oil, or a mixture of wine and oil, and all that cold substance.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	 Until the third day, as we said, then one should dissolve the swelling and cleanse the wound, and administer to its healing whatever is suitable for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	 This therefore is what is necessary from knowledge of universal treatment for swelling.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	 According to the aforementioned method of classification, I have already said about every kind of swelling, how it is directed towards its healing chapter by chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	 Of cutting out swelling that occurs on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	 Head XLI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	 Swellings on the skin of the head are small and belong to the species of Nodules, which consist of sacs that contain them like little bags of hens' nests.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	 And there are many kinds of these species.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	 Some of them are fatty; and some contain moisture similar to mud; and some contain moisture similar to scales and scabs; there are others like that, and among them are ones that are stone-hard.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	 And during the surgery on all of them, there is no fear for their extraction as long as it does not cause disruption to the blood vessels in its cutting process.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	 And the operation during their extraction is to try them with an instrument whose shape comes after these, which is called an Intrusion, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	 For if it contains moisture, then dry the extracted part by cutting along its length following the method of the surface cut: according to this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	 And begin with the cutting from line b to line g; therefore, as moisture is evacuated, then remove the growth that contains this moisture, and do not let anything be left in it thoroughly.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	 For often times it returns if something remains from there.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then immerse the cautery in Egyptian ointment if it is present: and if not, in water and salt; then fill with it the wound, and let it remain until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	 For indeed it consumes what remains from the growth.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat over the cautery with Egyptian ointment a second and third time; and if you see that it has not left anything from the growth, then care for the wound with ointment until healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	 If the abscess contains a pus node: then dry it following this form; having the shape of a cross for cutting: and project the little hooks between the bone ends, and remove it from all parts: and try your skill in extracting the envelope that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	 But if however an obstruction is made for you by the vessel, then do what I will tell you to do afterward.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	 And similarly proceed with an abscess if it is a stone: by cutting and the same care as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	 And the cutting over the abscess of a stone is easier: because there are few blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	 And sometimes these types of abscesses are located on the head of some men, with whom there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	 That is: because I have cut over an abscess on the head of a bald woman, and found an abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; and if it were struck with something being thrown at it by someone else, it would wound itself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	 In other cases of boils and such occurrences on the head, besides these apostemas that occur in children' cups, and near the roots of ears, a superficial section should be performed for all of them.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	 Or place a puncture on their always from the lower part of them, so that the course of pus may be relieved towards the bottom.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	 Then attend to it with what suits them in accordance with its treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	 § On cutting of Strophulae on the neck.
Caput XLII.	 Head XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	 Often these boils occur on the neck and under arms, and groins, and sometimes they occur in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	 And on top of these that occur on the neck, there are few and many: and they originate from sweat; and all Strophulae come from them within their own tunic, just as it is in nodes and boils of the head, as I have told you.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	 And there are many kinds of these Strophulae.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	 For from them indeed there are stones; and there are those that contain moisture; and there are harmful ones, which do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	 In this kind then that you see of good arrangement by touch, which is evident by the close color of skin, and it moves to all parts, and it is not joined with collar nerves, nor with jugular veins, nor with arteries, nor deep: one must cut it off with a superficial section from upper part downward toward lower part of body along line b. to line g., and pick out its skin edge by edging all around; or extend two lips of skin with hooks or many hooks if you find such thing as we said in head boils, and gradually extract it.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	 And it is to be observed carefully not to injure the vein, nor nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	 And it is a place not very sharp: so that it does not give you hand pain when making an incision, or trouble the sick person, and cut only what is necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	 However, if you fall and injure an artery or the wound is closed off from surgery, then place ground zigaretto (incense) or certain powders that stop blood flow into the wound, tighten the wound, and release it, until the swelling of pus subsides and the wound softens; or if it begins to start turning putrid.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	 Therefore, blood is stopped using a tourniquet from Robertus, so that you may finish your surgery.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	 Then examine with your index finger if anything remains from the staples or other materials: so cut them out and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	 If there is a large opening in the root of the staple: then it must not be cut from its own roots: rather it should be lightly loosested with a double strong thread and released so that it falls off on its own without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	 Then fill the wound completely with an old ointnent of Egypt which you have already submerged.
Deinde cura ipsum.	 Then take care of it. (Note: This instruction is
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	 If the entire staple is cut, then it must be gathered with two wound lips: and wash it immediately after seeing that nothing remains overabundant. (Note: This instruction assumes familiarity with ancient surgical procedures involving staples.)
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	 However, if you see that there remains an overabundance because of the size of the stapletechnology, then it must be tightened to cut its roots and extract it: and apply the suture as we mentioned before. (Note: This instruction assumes knowledge of historical surgical techniques involving sutures.)
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	 And what contains moisture from the staple should be punctured with a superficial perforation so that its healing place appears to you: and place the perforation below where it follows on the body as we said. (Note: This instruction assumes knowledge of historical surgical practices involving the management of wound moisture.)
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then administer liniment with ointment, and similar substances, to warm what remains from the decay until when you see that the wound is already cleaned: then take care of it with a regenerating ointment for the flesh, until it heals. (Note: This instruction assumes knowledge of historical surgical practices involving post-perforation treatments.)
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	 § On cutting the epiglottis due to an obstruction within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	 The ancients have said that this incision was made on the epiglaturm, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and this is their writing style.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	 However, in those with a tension pneumothorax, it is necessary that an incision be made on the epiglottis; because if this does not occur, then respiration cannot take place: therefore, because all vessels and lungs are sick.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	 In those who have a hot abscess in the mouth or throat, or in both tonsils, when there is no sickness in the canal, it should be used to make an incision on the epiglottis, to avoid destruction that occurs from perforation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	 Therefore, when we wish to do that incision on the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, a small cut perpendicular in width, between two circles for as much quantity as there is an incision in flesh and not cartilage: this place itself is suitable for cutting because it is devoid of fatty tissue, and vessels of blood are far from that area.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	 But if the physician is hesitant, then they should stretch out the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	 Then strike the skin until it reaches the canal; let out some blood vessels if you see anything coming from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	 Then cut the flesh as we have mentioned; and it signifies above the cutting of the canal from mucus that emerges from there, when something breaks off, and a cough is expelled.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	 And release an open wound after some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	 But when the hour is removed from which he fears perforation, bring together two lips of a skin wound and its own alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	 Then administer medicines that cause flesh to grow; until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	 Said Albuccian.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	 The sum of the tale we have told is not an explanation unless when they see that some of these boils have already closed up in the patient's throat: and the sick man rises above death, and wishes to cut off his breathing; so they come to cutting out the epiglottis, as for him to breathe upon the wound site, and is healed from death: and therefore it was prescribed to let open sores be removed until the malice of the sickness consumes completely, and its malevolence lasts three days or so; then they ordered to sew up the wound, and take care of it until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	 And what I have seen myself is that a maid took hold of a knife and thrust it into her own throat, and wounded herself with its edge.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	 And I was called to heal hers, and found her moaning as the cry of the dead is.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	 Therefore from the wound I dissected it, and found blood that had come out through the wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	 Therefore I was confused because she did not faint nor vomit: and a breath of air came out from the ward.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	 So I cared for the wound and treated it until healed; and nothing befell to the maid except a rasping voice: and she returned after days to better condition of her own.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	 Therefore I say: that there is no fear in cutting out an epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	 ¶ On the incision of a hernia in the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	 This hernia of the throat called 'Aposthoma' is a large boil according to the body's color: and it occurs frequently among women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	 And it is in two ways: for it may be natural or accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	 Certainerly, it cannot be an artifice naturally.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	 However, in the other way accidental, there are two kinds: one is like a node of pine cones.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	 And another kind is like an embolism that occurs due to vascatury.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	 And in it is fear, and one should not make a conjecture about this with iron unless in what is small; and you test the thing yourself, and investigate it by insertion.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	 If therefore you find it like a node of pine cones and is not hanging with any vessels: then cut out the thing as they do nodes: and extract it along with whatever contains from the sack, if it is in the sack; and if not, then examine its entirety.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then attend to the place as required for healing until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	 ¶ On cutting according to types of nodes. (This is not a translation instruction but part of the original text or
Caput XLV.	 Chapter XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	 There are many kinds of nodes, and I have already described all the kinds thereof in division: and it is necessary that I narrate herein a distinction between Node, and Embolism: since it creates doubt. (This text snippet doesn't contain instructions but rather appears to be part of an original work.)
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	 Therefore I say that when an Embolism is heat and fever and intense pains until the overflow of excess fluid subsides and putrefaction completes: then indeed the fevers calm down, and warmth subsides. (Again, this appears to be part of a larger work.)
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	 However when a Node is not heat nor fever nor pains, and it contains those sacs called siphachae, which are their own sacs according to the color of the body: and they arise suddenly like beans, and come forth like fennel, bigger and smaller ones. (Once more, part of a larger document.)
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	 And there are two kinds: fatty or containing moisture. (This is also not an instruction but text from the original work.)
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	 And there are many colors due to moisture, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	 Therefore, when you arrive at the treatment of the Node, you must examine it and ask about its form first with the instrument called Intromissum, as described in the chapter that follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	 And the method of inquiring about swellings and all nodes is to receive this instrument, insert it into a wetter place you find in the swelling: and gradually retract your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	 Then use your last finger according to the size of the swellings.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	 Next, remove the Intromebium and examine what comes out on its indication.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	 If then there runs a moisture, whatever the color is: then dry it with a cut that is superfebrile, as I said in other swellings.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	 And if there does not come out moisture in the indication of Intromissum, then know it is fatty: therefore dry above it with a cut that has a cross shape, according to this form as I taught you: and hang it with an unguentarium, and excoriate the skin from all sides easily: and if you can keep something on top of that, guard it with a kestros, so as to extract the healthy Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	 If however the unguentarium is broken during surgery, and it is not possible to extract it fully, because this often happens with that: then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	 For if something still remains from it a little or much, the Node returns greatly.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 But if it overcomes you and a little still remains from it: then fill the wound near your completion with some sharp abrasive powders: and bind the wound, and place on top of that which sits in hot swelling, and care for it as per the remaining treatment until healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	 If there is a large knot, then tie its two lips and care for it as it becomes inflamed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	 But if the blood vessel is pulsing or not: then hurry, and fill in the place with a pounded lint, and release it tightly for two days or three, until the wound putrefies and the boiling of blood ceases: then return to cutting off what remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	 § Of external instruments for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	 There are forms of probes; and they are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	 For from them there is a large one, and from them there is a medium one, and from them there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	 Let them be made of iron rectangular ends askew, so that they enter quickly into the extremities.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	 And these are forms of experients (probes), and not piercers; that is, perforators: and one of their names is called a berr, that is, a perforator: and they are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	 For from them there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	 They are fitted to be used for investigating through the extremities, and excised tissues, and fistulas, and boils arising between them from bone fragments.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	 And they are also made round, pointed, and blunt, as with large needles that follow the seats (beds), such as from amber indeed, or from copper, iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	 And their better ones are those made of amber.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	 And they are also made of black lead and used for investigating the fistulas whose refluxes (outflows) are mirror-like, which with their own smoothness cause reflection in harmony with those refluxe.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	 And again they are three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	 For from them there are long ones, and medium ones, and short ones, according to the amplitude of the fistulas and stricture (narrowing) it has.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	 The shape of cuts, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	 Since they are simple ones, namely those with a single passage: and there are three kinds as you see them - Great, Middle, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	 And among them are blind cuts, and there are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	 And among them are hooks with two passages and there are three kinds; and those are hooks with three passages and there are three kinds as well; and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	 And these are the shapes of scalpels by which nodes and boils are cut and scraped; and there are three kinds - Great, Medium, and Small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	 Their pointed ends are those with which cutting is done; the other ends are not sharp. And they do not have such shapes, unless for providing comfort during boil scraping when there is fear of a cut on the vein or nerve, and that it may be healed through them in cases where only slight burning was found to provide relief at the time of nodule scrapeing.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	 These are hooks with three passages, and there are three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	 They are made of iron, and they resemble an earthenware pipe with which alcohol is drawn; there is a small hole at the wider end hidden by Spatulae (surgical spreaders); and into it flows towards the interior or exterior depending on whether it's used as seen.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	 The shape of the spreaders hidden between fingers during boil puncturing; and they are not felt by patients: and there are three kinds - Great, Medium, and Small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	 The form of the blood vessel cutters with which bleeding flow is severed; and there are three kinds - Great, Medium, and Small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	 They should be made of copper or gold, round mostly in length as seen; and they are subtle.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	 And it should be that there are these types of tourniquets with you, large and small; so as to use them for cutting off blood quickly when necessary, and then when no medicine is present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	 However, do not use them for cutting off blood in every body part; and only use them on fleshly places: such as the shanks of legs, hips, arms' shoulders, breasts, winds, groins, and similar to these from fleshy parts, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	 And sometimes tools are made from them similar to cups of fistulae; which cuts off blood when it flows out of a wound or during an incision of veins, arteries: and at times there are made from them spherical ones according to this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	 § On the healing of human breasts which resemble women's breasts.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter LXXVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	 Sometimes breasts of some people are inflamed during the completion of sleep (that is, when they start to become sweaty during sleep): and remain with unsightly pustules.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	 But if one dislikes this, he should cut over the breasts using a crescent-shaped incision according to this method from point b, to point g: then remove all the swelling.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	 Then fill the wound with carnivorous medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And then gather two lips of the wound together with a stitch: and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	 But if it bends downwards and softens due to its size, as happens with women: then it should be cut in two of its upper sides at the same shape of a crescent-shaped incision, one of which contains the other on each side until the larger line encloses the smaller according to this method from point b, to point g. Then remove the skin that is between the two lips and take away the swelling, and apply what we have said about stitching and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	 However, if you cannot close the incision as it should be cut due to the patient'amoor or because of bleeding: then you must fill the wound with soaked cotton in a corrosive ointment and let it rest until that which remains from the swelling dries.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	 Regarding the puncture of abscesses that occurs under a boil.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	 These abscesses that occur under a boil are of the species called Strophulae, which contain bile and consist of them, and they are those containing moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 These therefore that contain moisture should be dried out with a crescent-shaped incision according to this pattern, from line b to line g, so that all the pus in the abscess is drained because of the discharge, then fill it with old cotton and let it rest until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then remove the cotton, and care for it with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	 If the abscess is of the species called Nodes of Strophulae, then cut over it as we have said in the incision above the Strophulae equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	 However, if the wound extends to such an extent that it discharges pus, then apply a caustic agent there as we have said in what was mentioned earlier.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	 Regarding the incision of abscessamoor that occurs due to an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	 When an artery is ruptured and the skin that is over it hardens, this often leads to abscesses from there: similarly, with veins as well, such things happen with abscesses and swelling.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	 And the signs by which one knows that abscesses and swelling are due to an artery and a vein are as follows: for when an abscess is because of an artery, it is long, clustered deep in the body; and when you push on an abscess with your fingers, you feel almost like there's a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	 And what is related to veins is round within the open body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	 And a section over this abscess is an error, especially when it is under the armpits, groins, neck, and in many body places; and it is very large indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	 Therefore, its care must be directed with iron, and what is also from it in the extremities or head should be treated accordingly.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	 Over this therefore from them arises due to an inflammamoent of the Artery's opening, it is found with a cut lengthwise into the skin.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	 Then open with hooks, afterwards the artery itself; and free it from the tunics until revealed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	 Then introduce under it a hook and make it penetrate to the other side, and bind the artery with a thread twice at two places, as I taught you in extracting the two arteries that are on the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	 Then strike the place between the two ligaments with a pincers until all blood that is within it flows out and the abscess dissolves.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then apply a treatment that generates pus until the ligaments fall; afterwards care for it with suitable ointments to that end when healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	 If the abscess is from a vein incision, then it must be held by your hand as much as possible away with skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	 Then insert a hook under the place you have held with your hand and make it penetrate; and be there a thread twice until extracted from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	 Then bind with the very abscess itself a good ligament: as I told you on the vein of two parts with two extremities thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	 But if the thread that is extracted a hook, then insert another with another thread under the abscess entirely at the incision of the needle: press and bind your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	 Then he cauterizes the abscess in its center until it protrudes; then incise the excess skin, and remove what is tied there.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	 Then place on top of that swelling which you have immersed in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then administer the treatment with licorice and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	 § About an abscess that occurs from a twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	 Head L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	 As it happens with an abscess in the Artery and Vein, similarly occurs with an abspect in Nerves: what happens to them is a blow, or from excessive labor, and similar causes: and they happen much more often at places of assistance, or heels, and in every place where they move joints: and it is a grave abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	 It resembles the color of other parts of the body, and it is found without pain in various dispositions: and when it tightens with great force, it feels weak like a state of stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	 And it is not an abscess accumulated deep within the body; rather, it is under the skin and moves to all parts of it without advancing forward or backward.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	 Therefore, when occurring at joints, one does not need it to advance with iron (scalpel).
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	 Perhaps there is a contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	 However, that which occurs at the head or forehead, has skin with pus-like substance.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	 If it is an abscess of glands, then hold it with forceps and cut it off at the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook and scrape off the abscess; next remove the piece, and bind the wound with stitches: and treat it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	 § About cutting an abscess that occurs at the genitalia.
Caput LI.	 Head LI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	 Certain very men often suffer from afflictions in their sinews and in other parts of their bodies, called thrushes, which are similar to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	 The root is thin, the head is thick, and they turn over the lips of those who have them.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	 And there are two kinds among them: one that is greatly esteemed.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	 And I myself have already seen men who had two thrushes that were more like other fungi: there was no difference between them; they were white and minute at the root, and turned over their lips, burst open, and always released moisture from within.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	 Therefore, I have cut into them, and found that one weighed about X pounds and VIII unciae (ounces), and the other VI unciae; thus consider: if the patient is moist and the thrushes are white, thin at the root, then you should incise it with a rather wide spatula, while there is caution in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 For often much blood is expelled during its sectioning; so be quick if your own blood overcomes you, then burn it with caution.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 If you see a patient who is cowardly and timid from the incision with iron, then take a thread made of lead properly formed, and tie it around the thrushes; as we have said before, let go of them after two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	 Then add to the lead string. (Note: The translation is complete, but this sentence seems incomplete or out of context
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	 Therefore do not cease to hold the lead string whenever it imprints on thrushes, until it separates and falls off naturally without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	 However, if there are thrushein large at the root, then there is something of fear and cowardice during its incision: especially because it's located inside a vein. (Note: The context may suggest that the size or location increases the difficulty or danger of treatment)
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	 However, it is possible to sever half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	 Then cauterize its body so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then care for the wound until it heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	 And be careful not to assume you are cutting something that is of a darker color, with few sensations and unpleasant appearance: for it is indeed an abscessed cancerous tumor; and I remember the treatment given by Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	 Regarding the treatment of enlargements at the navel.
Caput LII.	 Chapter LII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	 The enlargement at the navel is due to many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	 Or from fissures of the diaphrage, which is above the abdomen: and it comes out as a result of this through wind or bowels, just as happens with other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	 Or from blood that flows from the vein, or from the artery, as previously mentioned.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	 Or from wind being trapped there.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	 If however it is due to a diaphragmatic rupture and wind discharge: then it has the color similar to that of the body: and it is bloody without pain: and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	 And if it is due to bowel discharge, then the location of its release is more intense in variety as we have narrated.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	 When therefore you press it with your fingers, it hides: then it returns and there may be a sound associated with it: and it is greatly magnified at the bath entrance, causing painful swelling.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	 If however it is due to moisture, then it is bloody and does not hide when pressed with your hand, nor tighten or swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	 If however it is due to blood, then these signs appear as an abscess turning black at the edge.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	 And if however it is due to new flesh: then it is a serious abscess, large and hard, growing according to the amount of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	 If indeed it is due to windiness, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	 And the operation on that is such that then you must consider if there is prominence of the navel due to artery blood, or vein, or windiness; then it should be avoided from healing.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	 For there is fear and trembling, as I taught you in the chapter where I said stasis due to an artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	 But if there is prominence of the navel due to the bowels or wind: then one should instruct the sick person to keep their breathing steady and stand upright extendedly.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	 Then signs with warm wax around the entire navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	 Afterwards instruct it to lie between your hands over its back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	 Then surround with a wide bandage around the navel above the place where you marked it with hot wax.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	 Then extend medium stasis upwardly, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	 Then bind it around the navel with a strong thread or string from silk cord and make knots at the end of the tensioned ligament.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	 Then open up the extended stasis above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	 But if you find it already detached from the ligament: then extract the stasis and insert into the index finger, and push the intestine towards the interior of the bowels: and if you encounter wind, then take the content with a large hook, and cut away any excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	 But if it is opposite to you an artery or vein: then surround that much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	 Then come back to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	 And take two needles and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two neede
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	 Then bind the stasis at four places over the needles: and if you can, remove the needle, and leave the place until the extended flesh rots away: and it falls off by itself: or cut out when softened and rotted.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what is needed using ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	 If the prominence of the navel is from a flesh wound or moisture: then it should be cauterized as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	 And extract any blood or moisture that you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	 Then care for it with what is needed to strengthen the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	 On treating cancer.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter LIII. (Latin III = three, so
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	 Now we have mentioned the division of cancer types and how to treat them with medicines; also it should be treated from there using iron so that it does not ulcerate; and we have discussed cancers originating in the uterus, and the precautions for tren.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	 And the ancients have said that sometimes cancer is located where it can be completely removed: such as cancer in the nipples or thighs and similar cases, from body parts to be extracted entirely; especially when small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	 But when it is large and has been eradicated, one should not approach close to it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	 For I have not been able to cure any of them: nor have I seen anyone before me who has come to that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	 And the operation on it, when located as we have mentioned, is to precede and dissolve weakness by means of a black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	 Then use leeches if you find them with obvious swelling.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	 Then prepare the patient for treatment, where it is located with surgery.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	 Then throw out the hooks that are attached to it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	 Then cauterize it from all sides with a scalpel, according to examination until nothing remains of its roots; and let the blood flow out, and do not cut it quickly, rather press on spots, and cleanse away thick blood completely by hand or as much as possible there with tools.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 However, if bleeding prevents you due to a swoleblood from an incision of the artery or vein, then cauterize the vein until the blood separates.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with the remaining treatment until healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	 Regarding the treatment for Hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter LIV.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	 Now we have narrated the division of Hydrops and how water accumulamoins form; and signs of every type, as well as its treatment with drugs.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	 And those that are treated with iron are only of the type ascites alone; and they do not approach types of tympanitis nor hyposarcia completely, for these are deadly.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	 When you have already treated this type of tympanitis with drugs and the treatment has not succeeded: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	 For if weakness has already settled in him or there is another ailment besides Hydrops, such as coughing or sputum dissolution and similar conditions: then do not treat with iron, for that fear exists.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.
